trueNegatives.question: Hi, is there an efficient way to remove duplicates within a class using vector similarity? Thanks.
Why do I receive 500 errors from OpenAI when vectorising?

qnas.question: What is status 429 when connecting Weaviate with OpenAI?
qnas.answer: This error message indicates that you have hit your assigned rate limit for the OpenAI API, whereas see for example https://help.openai.com/en/articles/6891829-error-code-429-rate-limit-reached-for-requests

qnas.question: How can I query how many objects I have imported / uploaded of a particular class?
alternativeQuestions: How can I see the number of objects I have imported / uploaded of a particular class?
qnas.answer:
You can count the number of objects of a particular class as follows:

{
  Aggregate {
    CLASSNAME {
      meta {
        count
      }
    }
  }
}

whereas replace CLASSNAME with the name of your class

Also see https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/graphql-references/aggregate.html

qnas.question: How can I parse the result of the Java client response?
alternativeQuestions: How can I parse the Java client response?
qnas.answer:
The Java client returns JSON, which you have to parse yourself, e.g.

Result <GraphQLResponse> result = client.graphQL().get()...;
Object dataObject = result.getResult().getData();
ObjectMapper mapper = new ObjectMapper();
JsonNode dataNode = mapper.valueToTree(dataObject);

qnas.question: Are there any performance benchmarks for Weaviate?
alternativeQuestions: Is there a benchmark for the performance of Weaviate?
qnas.answer: Please see https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/benchmarks/ann.html

qnas.question: Is there a max length for class name?
alternativeQuestions: Can I get a class name max length?
qnas.answer:
There probably is an upper limit related to storage. The binary data on disk is typically stored in the fashion
bytes | description
| --- | --- |
| 0-4 | uint32 length indicator for upcoming content | 
| 4-n | payload |
So depending on what data type we use for storing the length indicator of the class name the max length is probably either 255 ( uint8 ) or 65k ( uint16 ) or 4e9 ( uint32 ), etc.

qnas.question: When is DiskANN, vector search on disk, planned to be released?
alternativeQuestions: When will you release DiskANN and disk vector search?
qnas.answer:
• A fully disk-based solution (comparable to DiskANN or rather FreshDiskANN) will be available during the first half of 2023
  • In Q1 (probably around the v1.18 release - EO February, 2023) we will have something else: Technically not disk-based, but also a big memory reduction without giving up recall or a lot of performance.

Also see

  • https://weaviate.io/blog/2022/10/ANN-algorithms-Vamana-vs-HNSW.html
  • https://github.com/erikbern/ann-benchmarks/

qnas.question: I have a class referencing other classes, can I do a nearText search also on the referenced classes?
alternativeQuestions: Can I do a nearText search on a referenced class?
qnas.answer:
Let's assume we have class User which is referencing the class Education and I want to get all users with the first name Charles and which have studied medicine.

Currently I cannot use nearText on the referenced class Education while searching on the class User , but I have to do this with two separate queries.

qnas.question: Is there a recommended way to create UUIDs that can be generated in a standardized way across different languages, e.g. Python and Javascript?
alternativeQuestions: In Python or Javascript, is there a recommended standard way to create UUIDs?
qnas.answer:
In the case of Python you can use for example

uuid. uuid5 ( namespace , name )

and in Javascript you can use for example

uuidv5(NAME, MY_NAMESPACE);

qnas.question: If I do not specify a UUID during adding data objects, will Weaviate create one automatically?
alternativeQuestions: Does Weaviate create UUIDs automatically, if I do not specify them?
qnas.answer: A UUID will be automatically created if not provided otherwise.

qnas.question: Is it possible to apply the QA module if I don't use text2vec module, but would like to use my own embeddings?
alternativeQuestions: Is it possible to use the QA module with my own embeddings?
qnas.answer:
According to https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/reader-generator-modules/qna-transformers.html the QA module depends on the text2vec module, which means in order to use the QA module one has to use the embeddings of the text2vec module.

But Weaviate is currently reviewing the QA module and tries to make it possible to use your own embeddings.

qnas.question: Does the Weaviate python client do string sanitization to prevent GraphQL injection attacks?
alternativeQuestions: Are GraphQL injection attacks prevented by Weaviate doing string sanitization in its python client?
qnas.answer:
The Weaviate python client itself doesn't do any sanitization, so it's up to you to ensure that input is properly sanitized before being passed to the Weaviate python client API.

There are various libraries which you can use to sanitize your input, e.g.

  • https://pypi.org/project/bleach/

whereas also see

  • https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/cheatsheets/GraphQL_Cheat_Sheet.html
  • https://docs.graphene-python.org/en/latest/quickstart/

qnas.question: How can I delete an object?
alternativeQuestions: How can I delete a class and all objects associated with this class?
Is there a way to delete all objects of a class without deleting the schema for the class?
qnas.answer:
Deleting an object is documented here resp. you can use the Batch Delete By Query where you can specify a where filter to define a set of ids that you want to delete simultaneously.

Deleting a class and all associated objects/data is documented here.

qnas.question: How can I configure the vector cache (RAM) size?
alternativeQuestions: Does updating vectorCacheMaxObjects automatically shrink / resize the vector cache size or do I have to restart Weaviate?
qnas.answer:
One can configure the vector cache size inside the schema, whereas see the parameter vectorCacheMaxObjects and see the documentation at https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/getting-started/schema.html

Please note that it is not necessary to restart Weaviate after modifying vectorCacheMaxObjects

When you use the Python client, then you can change the size of a class as follows:

client.schema.update_config("CLASS_NAME",{"vectorIndexConfig":{"vectorCacheMaxObjects": 1000000}})

qnas.question: How can I improve the performance to import data?
alternativeQuestions: What can I do to improve import performance of data?
qnas.answer:
Are you maybe using a neural model (e.g. t2v-transformers ) for vectorization without running with GPUs?

In that case the fix would be to use GPU-accelerated hardware for your model.

If you are not doing neural model-based vectorization at import time, then something else must be wrong as you should be able to import 10k entries in less than a minute on a somewhat recent laptop.

Since the inference happens in a separate container it would be enough to have the inference container on GPU-accelerated hardware. I.e. no need to pay for everything to run with GPUs if it’s only the model that needs one.

Also please see

  • https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/more-resources/performance.html
  • https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/architecture/resources.html
  • https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/benchmarks/ann.html

qnas.question: How can I contribute to Weaviate during Google Summer of Code?
alternativeQuestions: Is there is a GSoC project list regarding Weaviate?
How can I be a GSOC contributor of weaviate?
qnas.answer:
Weaviate will look to participate in the next edition of GSoC, but there is still time until the summer :-)

In the meantime you might want to contact our head of DevRel Sebastian Witalec re ideas and participation.

qnas.question: How do I update Weaviate?
alternativeQuestions: How is Weaviate updated correctly?
qnas.answer:
• Either update the version set by the parameter "image" inside your docker-compose.yml file ...
  • ... or recreate a new docker-compose.yml file using the Weaviate configuration tool at https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/installation/docker-compose.html#configurator
  • Shutdown Weaviate: docker-compose down
  • Startup Weaviate: docker-compose up -d
  • Check logs: docker-compose logs -f

qnas.question: How can I best contribute to Weaviate?
alternativeQuestions: Is there a way to contribute to Weaviate?
qnas.answer:
Please see the following resources in order to contribute to Weaviate:

  • https://weaviate.io/developers/contributor-guide/current/
  • https://github.com/semi-technologies/weaviate/blob/master/CONTRIBUTE.md

qnas.question: Does Weaviate support UPSERT for the batch endpoint?
alternativeQuestions: Is UPSERT for the batch endpoint supported in Weaviate?
qnas.answer:
As long as your objects have unique IDs, you could technically resend the entire batch. In this case the batch would work like an UPSERT, where the existing objects would be replaced, rather than created. If you’re not assigning IDs this would not work, however, as Weaviate would created duplicates for the ones that were imported successfully.

Also see https://weaviate.slack.com/archives/C017EG2SL3H/p1665070172390889

qnas.question: How can I determine the memory / RAM usage?
alternativeQuestions: Where can I see the RAM usage?
qnas.answer:
The following page describes how to plan your resources

https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/architecture/resources.html#the-role-of-memory

Based on the link above, you can determine what your memory requirements should be for your given case.

If there is a small difference (less than 20%) between the estimated calculation and the actual usage, then I’d say all is correct and you simply need to run with more memory.

If there is a large discrepancy between both values, then it could be an indication that something is off and requires further investigation.

Generally it is to be expected that as you add more data, the memory requirements grow, as the HNSW vector index is memory-based.

qnas.question: For custom dataset, how should it be formatted in order to work well with the Weaviate extractor?
alternativeQuestions: What format does the Weaviate extractor prefer from custom datasets?
qnas.answer: You can add any data object through the batch data import API, with schema or without schema .

qnas.question: Why do I get the error message "store is read-only"?
alternativeQuestions: How to modify the configuration of disk usage threshold?
qnas.answer:
Could it be that your disk is full? The read only was introduced as a fail-save because when the disk runs full data loss is guaranteed. If you check your weaviate logs, you should see a warning at 80% disk full and a fail-safe at 90% that makes everything read-only. You can configure those percentages if they are too low for you by reconfiguring

  • DISK_USE_WARNING_PERCENTAGE
  • DISK_USE_READONLY_PERCENTAGE

But running out of disk space is always going to be an issue, even if you turn off the warnings.

qnas.question: Which similarity metrics does Weaviate support?
alternativeQuestions: which similarity metrics are used by Weaviate?
qnas.answer:
Weaviate implements various similarity metrics, e.g.

  • Dot product
  • Cosine similarity
  • l2-squared
  • Manhattan distance
  • Hamming distance

whereas see

  • https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/vector-index-plugins/distances.html
  • https://weaviate.io/blog/2022/09/Distance-Metrics-in-Vector-Search.html
  • https://github.com/semi-technologies/weaviate/tree/master/adapters/repos/db/vector/hnsw/distancer
  • Hamming distance as an example, how to add your own distance metric: https://github.com/semi-technologies/weaviate/pull/2048/files

qnas.question: Can you set an OpenAI API key on the hosted version?
alternativeQuestions: Does the hosted version support OpenAI API keys?
qnas.answer:
Starting with v1.11.0 the OPENAI_APIKEY environment variable is now optional inside the docker-compose configuration and you can instead provide the key at insert/query time as an HTTP header.

See https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/retriever-vectorizer-modules/text2vec-openai.html

qnas.question: Is there any way to get a total count of objects in a class?
alternativeQuestions: How do I get the total count of objects of a class?
qnas.answer: You can get the total count of objects in a class with meta { count } in the Aggregate{} function, whereas see https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/graphql-references/aggregate.html

qnas.question: When scalar and vector search are combined, will the scalar filter happen before or after the nearest neighbor (vector) search?
alternativeQuestions: In a combined approach, which will happen first, scalar filter or nearest neighbour vector search?
qnas.answer:
The mixed structured vector searches in Weaviate are pre-filter.

There is an inverted index which is queried first to produce an allow-list.

This list is passed onto the HNSW index, which ignores objects which aren’t on the allow list

Also see https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/architecture/prefiltering.html

qnas.question: How can I rotate the logs of my Weaviate container?
alternativeQuestions: Can I switch out the logs of a Weaviate container?
qnas.answer:
Weaviate takes a cloud native / 12 factor app methodology approach to logs , where log events are sent to stdout and the orchestration system (i.e. Docker or Kubernetes) will handle the logs.

In Kubernetes the log rotation is automatic.

Using Docker on Linux, the log of a container is located at /var/lib/docker/containers/{container-id}/{container-id}-json.log and the log rotation can be done for example with https://hub.docker.com/r/blacklabelops/logrotate or you can also configure the Docker daemon .

qnas.question: Does Weaviate have the concept of tables, similar to relational databases?
alternativeQuestions: Are there tables in Weaviate?
qnas.answer:
A Weaviate schema consists of one ore more classes, whereas see

  • https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/tutorials/how-to-create-a-schema.html
  • https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/restful-api-references/schema.html

qnas.question: Do you know when the hybrid search (BM25 + semantic search) will be available?
alternativeQuestions: When is the BM25 + semantic hybrid search method release?
qnas.answer:
You can follow the progress of Hybrid Search in this ticket:

https://github.com/semi-technologies/weaviate/issues/2134

The team is currently working on the design/requirements for initial implementation.

qnas.question: Are there any limitation on the open source distribution?
alternativeQuestions: Is there some sort of enterprise license for on-prem installations?
qnas.answer: There is no limitation on the open source distribution and no split licencing. We do offer a cloud service here  https://weaviate.io/pricing.html

qnas.question: Has anyone deployed Weaviate in Azure?
alternativeQuestions: Are there any experiences of Weaviate being deployed in Azure?
qnas.answer:
We recommend deploying weaviate in an AKS (Azure Kubernetes Service) cluster on a Compute Optimised Nodes with at least 4 CPUs. The CPUs and Memory resources can be adjusted according to this page, depending on the data and the application you want to build: https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/architecture/resources.html

Also we recommend deploying Weaviate using helm . Here is a script that does this:

#!/bin/bash set -eou pipefail export NAMESPACE="weaviate" CHART_VERSION="15.0.0-alpha.2" WEAVIATE_VERSION="1.14.1" echo "Installing or upgrading weaviate helm chart installation to namespace '$NAMESPACE'" helm repo add weaviate https://semi-technologies.github.io/weaviate-helm/ helm repo update helm upgrade \ "weaviate" \ weaviate/weaviate \ --version "$CHART_VERSION" \ --install \ --namespace "$NAMESPACE" \ --create-namespace \ --values ./weaviate-values.yaml \ --set "image.tag=$WEAVIATE_VERSION"

Where the weaviate-values.yaml is this one: https://github.com/semi-technologies/weaviate-helm/blob/master/weaviate/values.yaml

NOTE: The storage class by default is premium-rwo which is a GCP specific, you would have to choose one that is supported by Azure. Here is how you can create custom storage classes, the example is the preferred storage class: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/aks/concepts-storage#storage-classes Use the metadata.name for the storage.storageClassName in the weaviate-values.yaml .

qnas.question: What is the best way to iterate through objects? Can I do paginated API calls?
alternativeQuestions: Is there a way to paginate through results while listing data objects here: https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/restful-api-references/objects.html#list-all-data-objects? By default it seems to return only 25 entries. I can e.g. use ?limit=9999 parameter to get all the objects (if there is less than 9999 of them), but is there more performant approach?
qnas.answer: The only way to paginate through the results in Weaviate is to use  limit  and  offset  params. Those params work both for  REST  and  GraphQL  requests. There's no other, more efficient way of paginating through the results then to use  limit  and  offset  params.

qnas.question: Can we get the distances/scores for each result?
alternativeQuestions: How can we get individual distances or scores for each result?
qnas.answer: You can get the distance and certainty by specifying them as additional GraphQL properties, whereas please see https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/graphql-references/additional-properties.html

qnas.question: I would like to search text files in a directory of my filesystem. What are the steps that I need to take to do this?
alternativeQuestions: How can I search text files in a folder of my filesystem?
qnas.answer: Please see the tutorials at https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/tutorials/index.html

qnas.question: I tried to make many continuous writes (lasts for hours) and noticed the memory consumption keeps increasing in a linear fasion and never plateau. Wondering what would be the intuition behind this and whether this is normal?
alternativeQuestions: Is it normal, that my memory consumption grows linearly while doing continuous writes?
qnas.answer:
Reducing Dimensionality
The biggest cost-saving is often in reducing the dimensionality of the data set. Let’s say for example you’d be using 768d vectors and could achieve the same accuracy with 384d ones, this would be a good saving already. Of course I don’t know anything about your dataset, and it may already be optimal for your needs, but since you mentioning cutting it half, it sounds like there might be some saving potential

Vector Cache
The hybrid solution you are currently hinting it is limiting the amount of vectors that are held in memory. You can simply do this by setting the vectorCacheMaxObjects to a value smaller than your dataset size. The handling of vectors from disk vs memory is fully automatic, you don’t have to do anything. There is however a big caveat: An import is essentially a search. So if you import with a large percentage of your vectors stored on disk your import speed will drop considerable.

Better memory management in v1.15
The next Weaviate release (v1.15) will be compiled with Go 1.19 which allows for far better memory management by automatically tuning the Garbabe-Collector. This means you will be able to use more of the memory you actually have. Expect an extensive blog post on this in the next 2 weeks.

Fully disk-based Vector Indexing
Our Vector R&D team is currently working on a fully disk-based ANN solution. In the future, you will be able to index primarily on disk. This solution will still require some memory, but it will be able to cut down the memory considerably with this completely new index type.

qnas.question: I want to rename a schema class... how can I do this?
alternativeQuestions: How can I rename a schema class?
qnas.answer:
It is not possible to rename a schema class, you can delete it and create a new one, no need to delete the whole schema. Deleting a schema class will delete all the objects of that class though.

Also see https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/restful-api-references/schema.html#update-a-class

qnas.question: Is it possible to add an additional property to a schema without losing the existing data?
alternativeQuestions: Can I extend a schema with another property without losing data?
qnas.answer: Please see https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/restful-api-references/schema.html#add-a-property

qnas.question: It seems like a class has 1 and only one vector associated with it?
alternativeQuestions: Does a class only have 1 vector?
qnas.answer: Weaviate only supports a single vector for a single record of a class.

qnas.question: Running into this:`nested clause at pos 1: invalid search term, only stopwords provided. Stopwords can be configured in class.invertedIndexConfig.stopwords',`Do I get it right, that this settings are applied on ingestion? So now when I am in production I’m  out of luck ? I need to drop all data and recreate from scratch? :tired_face:And is there a way how to just ignore this error? I can’t control what query user types into search field…
alternativeQuestions: I'm getting this error: `nested clause at pos 1: invalid search term, only stopwords provided. Stopwords can be configured in class.invertedIndexConfig.stopwords' do I have to drop all data and recreate the index? or can I just ignore the error somehow?
qnas.answer: Unfortunately if you search with only stopwords you will get the above error "invalid search term, only stopwords provided". Options would be reindex with stopwords disabled (preset : none) or catch the error in your application and return no results in this scenario

qnas.question: Is it possible to parallelize any part of adding data to Weaviate?
alternativeQuestions: Can data ingestion be parallelized?
qnas.answer: Since the model containers are typically completely stateless you can simply scale them horizontally. Depending on how you chose to do that you mean a simple load balancer in front of the scaled out containers, e.g. a simple nginx that round-robins across the containers. Or - if you’re running e.g. on K8s, you might rely on a K8s service doing that for you.

qnas.question: What’s the error meaning check the DerivedFromError field for more information?
alternativeQuestions: check the DerivedFromError field for more information. what does that error mean?
qnas.answer:
Unfortunately that's an inconvenience in the way that Go client handles errors. If you want to get the actual error from the DerivedFromError field you can use this small portion of code: 
func getErrorMsg(err error) string {
	msg := ""
	if err != nil {
		msg = err.Error()
		weaviateError, ok := err.(*fault.WeaviateClientError)
		if ok {
			msg = fmt.Sprintf("%s %v", msg, getErrorMsg(weaviateError.DerivedFromError))
		}
	}
	return msg
}

qnas.question: How to use Weaviate with your own vectors? (No modules, pure vector storage and search)
alternativeQuestions: Is it possible to provide vectors directly or do you have to let Weaviate handle the embedding?
qnas.answer:
Please see

  • https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/tutorials/how-to-use-weaviate-without-modules.html
  • https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/graphql-references/filters.html#nearvector-filter
  • https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/architecture/storage.html

You need to add include=vectors to get the vectors after you imported them

http://localhost:8080/v1/objects?include=vector vs http://localhost:8080/v1/objects

whereas see https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/restful-api-references/objects.html

If you want to pull the vectors out when doing a search in graphql you specify vectors under _additional fields.

qnas.question: Is there any way to make some properties of classes required or optional. If so, how would I specify this in the schema?
alternativeQuestions: Can I specify in the schema that some properties are optional or required?
qnas.answer: Please see the following thread https://weaviate.slack.com/archives/C017EG2SL3H/p1648052161980189

qnas.question: Are there any 'best practices' or guidelines to consider when designing a schema? E.g. if I was looking to perform a semantic search over a the content of a Book would I look to have Chapter and Paragraph represented in the schema etc, would this be preferred over including the entire content of the novel in a single property?
alternativeQuestions: I am looking for best practices on designing a schema. For example how would a book be structured in a schema, as a whoole in one property or by chapters or by paragraphs?
qnas.answer:
As a rule of thumb, the smaller the units, the more accurate the search will be. Two objects of e.g. a sentence would most likely contain more information in their vector embedding than a common vector (which is essentially just the mean of sentences). At the same time more objects leads to a higher import time and (since each vector also makes up some data) more space. (E.g. when using transformers, a single vector is 768xfloat32 = 3KB. This can easily make a difference if you have millions, etc.) of vectors. As a rule of thumb, the more vectors you have the more memory you’re going to need. So, basically, it’s a set of tradeoffs. Personally we’ve had great success with using paragraphs as individual units, as there’s little benefit in going even more granular, but it’s still much more precise than whole chapters, etc. You can use cross-references to link e.g. chapters to paragraphs. Note that resolving a cross-references takes a slight performance penalty. Essentially resolving A1->B1 is the same cost as looking up both A1 and B1 indvidually. This cost however, will probably only matter at really large scale.

One option with Weaviate could be the following:
  1. Vectorize a summary or title + introduction
  2. Include the full text of a document (length limited to some sane number) in a text field. Skip vectorization for this field if using modules.
  3. When searching, do a full text search (where clause) combined with a near vector clause (for ranking)
 
Another option would be to paginate the data and store each page/paragraph as a separate document in Weaviate. This would be useful if you are looking to find information inside multi-page documents vs just finding a relevant document.

Also see https://app.katie.qa/#/read-answer?domain-id=ceb2d2f2-2c1d-49be-a751-eed4be19e021&uuid=01b1cc49-0035-419d-a0fc-707a30117216

qnas.question: Let's assume we have a lot of full text from digitized books that we could index and query in Weaviate using Transformers. I'm wondering though: what exactly should we index? Every single sentence? Every paragraph? Every chapter? Entire books? Are there guidelines or best practices somewhere?
alternativeQuestions: Are there any 'best practices' or guidelines to consider when designing a schema? E.g. if I was looking to perform a semantic search over a the content of a Book would I look to have Chapter and Paragraph represented in the schema etc, would this be preferred over including the entire content of the novel in a single property?
qnas.answer:
There is no absolute guideline and it will definitely vary from use case to use case. It seems that paragraph level provides the best results. Single sentence may lose meaning if they are taken out of context and whole chapters typically makes it too hard to retrieve something meaningful. In the Weaviate Wikipedia example paragraphs were used, for example, and the results in general work quite well.

Also see

  • https://app.katie.qa/#/read-answer?domain-id=ceb2d2f2-2c1d-49be-a751-eed4be19e021&uuid=2d648c73-f72d-4932-b1f7-6adc5c68e77a
  • https://app.katie.qa/#/read-answer?domain-id=ceb2d2f2-2c1d-49be-a751-eed4be19e021&uuid=e0251a5c-c35c-4ba8-b564-17aacb8692a6

qnas.question: How can I index a folder of PDF files, break them down into chunks, and then let me search using text or image for relevant chunks?
alternativeQuestions: Is there a way to index a directory of PDF files and search it in parts by text or image search?
qnas.answer: See for example https://github.com/alexcg1/example-pdf-search

qnas.question: Hi community,Is it possible for now to use custom ONNX sentence-transformers models in production with Weaviate?
alternativeQuestions: Is there a way to use a custom ONNX sentence-transformer model in weaviate while in production?
qnas.answer: You can generate the vectors on your own…as for using transformers module, it’s a docker container… you’d need to build your own… it is open source however, so simply forking it and modifying in order to use ONNX should do the trick I think.

qnas.question: How does Weaviate's vector and scalar filtering work?
alternativeQuestions: Does Weaviate use pre- or post-filtering ANN index search?
qnas.answer:
It’s a 2-step process:

  1. The inverted index (which is built at import time) queries to produce an allowed list of the specified document ids. Then the ANN / HNSW index is queried with this allow list (the list being one of the reasons for our custom implementation).
  2. If we encounter a document id which would be a close match, but isn’t on the allow list the id is treated as a candidate (i.e. we add it to our list of links to evaluate), but is never added to the result set. Since we only add allowed IDs to the set, we don’t exit early, i.e. before the top `k` elements are reached.

Note that there is a point - when a filter is very restrictive, e.g., matching 100 out of 1B ids - the above process becomes less efficient. In that case it would be much, much cheaper to simply perform a brute-force search on the remaining 100 vectors. This is a future optimiziation that we have planned, but which is not implemented yet.

For more information on the technical implementations, see this video .

qnas.question: Does a batch update API exist, similar to the batch upload API?
alternativeQuestions: Is there a batch upload API, but instead of uploading it's updating?
qnas.answer: For now it doesn't. Could you please describe your use case a bit more for this?

qnas.question: How can I query the text of one class and filter by another referenced class?
alternativeQuestions: Is there a way to filter by a referenced class while querying another class?
qnas.answer:
The following link describes how one can query the text of one class and filter by another referenced class.

For example if you have a class to describe a Product and a class to describe a Review of a Product, whereas the Review is referencing the Product which it is about. Let's assume to you want to query the text of all reviews and at the same time filter by a particular Product property.

For this use case please see https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/graphql-references/filters.html#beacon-reference-filters

qnas.question: Why isn't there a text2vec-contextionary in my language?
alternativeQuestions: I'm looking for a text2vec-contextionary in another language, is there one?
qnas.answer:
The contextionary models cannot be replaced with custom models, therefore you are limited to the out-of-the-box languages which currently include English, Dutch, German, Czech, Italian .

Also see https://stackoverflow.com/questions/71936334/what-languages-does-weaviate-support

Ping us here on Github , and we will make sure in the next iteration it will become available (unless you want it in Silbo Gomero or another language which is whistled).

qnas.question: How can I protect the APIs of my own Weaviate server?
alternativeQuestions: Is there a way to guard my Weaviate server APIs?
qnas.answer:
Weaviate exposes APIs and if you want to expose them to the outside world without people messing up your instance you can do this with an Nginx reverse proxy.

Here is an example configuration, whereas it assumes that Weaviate runs on port 4001

https://github.com/wyona/katie-weaviate/blob/master/nginx.conf

If you want to shield off all access (not just write access like above) you can also set a simple mechanism such as basic auth or JWT authentication in front of all endpoints, whereas see for example

  • https://medium.com/pernod-ricard-tech/adding-basic-authentication-with-nginx-as-a-reverse-proxy-a229f9d12b73
  • https://docs.nginx.com/nginx/admin-guide/security-controls/configuring-jwt-authentication/

Also see related QnA: How can I configure Weaviate that Weaviate accepts requests only from localhost?

qnas.question: Are the returned objects sorted in any order by default when I use ask()?
alternativeQuestions: Is there a default sorting order when using ask()?
qnas.answer: The objects will be sorted by certainty   whereas also see https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/v1.11.0/reader-generator-modules/qna-transformers.html

qnas.question: With your aggregations I could not see how to do time buckets, is this possible?
alternativeQuestions: Is it possible to create time buckets while aggregating?
qnas.answer: At the moment, we cannot aggregate over timeseries into time buckets yet, but architecturally there's nothing in the way. If there is demand, this seems like a nice feature request, you can submit an issue here .

qnas.question: How does the HNSW indexer deal with duplicate vectors? I have a dataset in which I'm certain there are duplicate images - so their vector embeddings will be the identical. Does this upset HNSW or degrade the performance of search in any way?
alternativeQuestions: Is HNSW performance impacted by duplicates vectors in a dataset?
qnas.answer: Performance does degrade with duplicates, yes. Whether that's a problem or not depends on the amount. With the ef and efConstruction values you basically control how many vectors are considered candidates at any point. Let's say you're considering 100 candidates and two of them are identical. That's not a big problem. However if all 100 are identical, that becomes a pretty noticeable performance issue.

qnas.question: Does Weaviate support dot product similarity when using the python sdk?
alternativeQuestions: Using the python SDK, can I use dot product similarity in Weaviate?
qnas.answer: Please see https://stackoverflow.com/questions/72031398/does-weaviate-support-dot-product-similarity-when-using-the-python-sdk

qnas.question: Are there restrictions on UUID formatting? Do I have to adhere to any standards?
alternativeQuestions: Are there UUID format standards I have to keep in mind?
qnas.answer: The UUID must be presented as a string matching the Canonical Textual representation . If you don’t specify a UUID, Weaviate will generate a v4 i.e. a random UUID. If you generate them yourself you could either use random ones or deterministically determine them based on some fields that you have. For this you’ll need to use v3 or v5 . There are plenty of python packages available to do this.

qnas.question: Does Weaviate support a keyword based fulltext search?
alternativeQuestions: Is there keyword based fulltext search in Weaviate?
qnas.answer: We're currently implementing BM25 functionality which will then give you the ability to score your results using sparse metrics. The next step is then coming up with mechanisms to combine both dense and sparse.

qnas.question: How to configure the size of my instance?
alternativeQuestions: What should I do to configure the size of my instance?
qnas.answer: You can find this in the architecture section of the docs.

qnas.question: Why did you use GraphQL instead of SPARQL?
alternativeQuestions: What is the reason for using GraphQL instead of SPARQL?
qnas.answer:
Two words, user experience. We want to make it as simple as possible to integrate Weaviate into your stack, and we believe that GraphQL is the answer to this. The community and client libraries around GraphQL are enormous, and you can use almost all of them with Weaviate.

One possibility to run queries is using the Weaviate console:

  • https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/getting-started/quick-start.html#query-via-the-weaviate-console
  • https://console.semi.technology/

qnas.question: Can I store binary data (for examples images) inside Weaviate?
alternativeQuestions: Can I store different data inside of Weaviate? for example images
qnas.answer:
You need to store binary data outside of Weaviate, but you can always link your binary data with Weaviate by adding a document / image url field to your schema class and save that information along with the vector data in Weaviate.

Blob data type in Weaviate is designed to store base64 encoded image data string. If you want to vectorise image data then you should pick Blob type for storing base64 image data.

We don't support storing of JSON data but if you would like to store JSON information along the vectorised image in Weaviate, then I would recommend just to add string property to your schema class and save that data along with Weaviate's object.

qnas.question: Does weaviate support bulk deletes?
alternativeQuestions: Is there bulk deletes in Weaviate?
qnas.answer: Please see https://stackoverflow.com/questions/71649305/does-weaviate-support-bulk-deletes

qnas.question: What languages does Weaviate support?
alternativeQuestions: Is there a list of languages that are supported by Weaviate?
qnas.answer:
Programming languages
Weaviate itself is written in Go, but most likely this has no influence on how you interact with it. Weaviate can be used language-agnostic using it's GraphQL and/or REST API. Additionally there are native language clients for Python, Go, Java and Javascript/Node. Other clients may be added in the future and if your favorite language is missing, you can contribute a client yourself.

Human languages / NLP
Weaviate Core (the pure database) is language-agnostic, it only knows objects and vectors. However, you might be interacting with Weaviate with one of our modules and they each support different languages, outlined below.

Text2vec-transformers / multi2vec-clip
You can plug in any transformers model, public or private, so there is no limitation to languages. The out-of-the-box models are typically either English or Multi-lingual

QnA-transformers
Similarly, the QnA module supports any custom module, so if you can find one in the language of your choice you can plug it in or train one yourself. The out-of-the-box modules currently all run in English.

Text2vec-contextionary
The contextionary models cannot be replaced with custom models, therefore you are limited to the out-of-the-box languages which currently include English, Dutch, German, Czech, Italian.

Text-Spellcheck
The spell-check module currently supports English, Dutch, and German, whereas also see https://app.katie.qa/#/read-answer?domain-id=ceb2d2f2-2c1d-49be-a751-eed4be19e021&uuid=511aa289-361f-4b39-bbd0-84d286645f20

qnas.question: How to change the maximum query results?
alternativeQuestions: Can I change the maximum of query results?
qnas.answer:
If you must retrieve more than 10,000 objects, you can increase this limit by setting the environment variable QUERY_MAXIMUM_RESULTS=<desired-value> , whereas please make sure to restart the Docker container such that the configuration is being applied.

Also see https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/graphql-references/filters.html

qnas.question: What is a good starting point to learn more about Weaviate?
alternativeQuestions: Is there a Getting-Started guide for Weaviate?
qnas.answer: Please see https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/getting-started/quick-start.html

qnas.question: Does Weaviate use Hnswlib?
alternativeQuestions: Is Hnswlib being used by Weaviate?
qnas.answer:
Weaviate does not use Hnswlib.

Weaviate uses a custom implementation of HNSW that overcomes certain limitations of hnswlib , such as durability requirements, CRUD support, pre-filtering, etc.

Custom HNSW implementation in Weaviate references:

  • HNSW plugin (Github)
  • vector dot product ASM

More information:

  • Weaviate, an ANN Database with CRUD support – DB-Engines.com ⬅️ best resource on the topic
  • Weaviate’s HNSW implementation in the docs

Note I: HNSW is just one implementation in Weaviate, but Weaviate can support multiple indexing algoritmns as outlined here

qnas.question: Where can I find an architecture overview respectively diagram of Weaviate?
alternativeQuestions: Is there an architecture overview diagram of Weaviate?
qnas.answer: Please see https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/architecture/index.html

qnas.question: How can slow queries be optimized?
alternativeQuestions: Can you help me optimize slow queries?
qnas.answer: Queries containing deeply nested references that need to be filtered or resolved can take some time. Read on optimization strategies here .

qnas.question: What languages does the spellcheck module support?
alternativeQuestions: Is there a list of languages that are supported by the spellcheck module?
qnas.answer:
The following languages are currently supported

  • Dutch
  • English
  • German

whereas see the various Docker images at https://hub.docker.com/r/semitechnologies/text-spellcheck-model/tags?page=1&name=1.0.2

Please see as well https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/modules/spellcheck.html

qnas.question: How does Weaviate scale horizontally?
alternativeQuestions: What is Weaviates horizontal scaling capability?
qnas.answer: Please see https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/current/getting-started/installation.html#kubernetes-k8s

qnas.question: Why do the operators Equal and NotEqual not match the provided full string value?
alternativeQuestions: Is there a way to search for an exact phrase / combination of words, e.g. "light blue"?
qnas.answer: At the moment, data type string uses a minimal tokenization logic that splits at the word level. See https://github.com/semi-technologies/weaviate/issues/1821

qnas.question: What is best practice for updating data?
alternativeQuestions: Is there a guide for updating data?
qnas.answer:
1. Use the batch API

2. Start with a small-ish batch size e.g. 100 per batch. Adjust up if it is very fast, adjust down if you run into timeouts

3. If you have unidirectional relationships (e.g. Foo -> Bar .) it's easiest to first import all Bar objects, then import all Foo objects with the refs already set. If you have more complex relationships, you can also import the objects without references, then use the /v1/batch/references API to set links between classes in arbitrary directions.

qnas.question: Can I use Weaviate for face recognition?
alternativeQuestions: Is face recognition something I can do with Weaviate?
qnas.answer:
Yes, whereas which face images have been imported and which face images have not been imported has a huge impact on the result quality, since there will always be a nearest neighbor. Even when it’s quite far away. You might want to to confirm a face only if the certainty/distance matches a specific threshold and otherwise showing something like “face not recognized”.

Also see https://www.semi.technology/developers/weaviate/current/modules/img2vec-neural.html

qnas.question: How can I find similar images to a given image?
alternativeQuestions: Given an image, can I search for a similar one?
qnas.answer:
See

  • Add an image to Weaviate: https://www.semi.technology/developers/weaviate/current/modules/img2vec-neural.html#adding-image-data-objects
  • Search for similar images using a given image as input: https://www.semi.technology/developers/weaviate/current/modules/img2vec-neural.html#nearimage-search

qnas.question: Can I connect my own module?
alternativeQuestions: Is there a way to add a custom module?
qnas.answer: Yes!

qnas.question: Does Weaviate support BM25 querys in a text field?
alternativeQuestions: Can I use BM25 queries in a text field in Weaviate?
qnas.answer: Not yet, but very soon, whereas see https://github.com/semi-technologies/weaviate/issues/1798

qnas.question: Is it possible to create one-to-many relationships in the schema?
alternativeQuestions: Can I declare one-to-many relationships in a schema?
qnas.answer: Yes, it is possible to reference to one or more objects (Class -> one or more Classes) through cross-references. This example shows how the `hasArticles` has references to the `Article` class.

qnas.question: How can I configure Weaviate that Weaviate accepts requests only from localhost?
alternativeQuestions: Can I configure Weaviate so that only localhost requests are accepted?
qnas.answer:
In the docker-compose file add the localhost address to the ports configuration

services:
  weaviate:
    ports:
    - 127.0.0.1:8080:8080

qnas.question: How can I import a schema?
alternativeQuestions: How is a schema imported?
qnas.answer:
Please see

  • https://www.semi.technology/developers/weaviate/current/tutorials/how-to-create-a-schema.html
  • https://www.semi.technology/developers/weaviate/current/restful-api-references/schema.html#create-a-class

Or try the following example:

curl -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d '{"class":"Qna", "description":"Question and Answer", "properties":[ {"dataType":["string"], "description":"Question", "name":"question" }, {"dataType":["string"], "description":"Answer", "name":"answer" } ] }' http://0.0.0.0:8080/v1/schema

or

curl -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d '{"class":"Qna", "description":"Question and Answer", "properties":[ {"dataType":["string"], "description":"Question", "name":"question", "moduleConfig":{"text2vec-transformers":{"skip":true}} }, {"dataType":["string"], "description":"Answer", "name":"answer" } ] }' http://0.0.0.0:8080/v1/schema

Or see the following shell script

https://github.com/wyona/katie-weaviate/blob/master/weaviate-schema.sh

qnas.question: How do I know which property of the class Weaviate searches through?
alternativeQuestions: Which property of a class is being searched by Weaviate?
qnas.answer: It's set in the schema which the user defines. Also see the api endpoint /v1/schema.

qnas.question: What causes a segmentation violation?
alternativeQuestions: When getting segmentation violations, what could be the causes?
qnas.answer: A segment violation means that Weaviate would try to access memory that had already been released to the operating system. This is something you should never see and most likely an indication of a bug.

qnas.question: What's the ideal way to check if an object exists on weaviate without retrieving it?
alternativeQuestions: Is there a way to check whether an object exists on Weaviate?
qnas.answer:
Please see the feature request

https://github.com/semi-technologies/weaviate/issues/1784

qnas.question: How can I monitor the Weaviate logs?
alternativeQuestions: Is there a tutorial about Weaviate logs?
qnas.answer:
If you're using docker compose, and have the containers running in the background, you can use the docker compose logs command:

$ docker-compose logs -f --timestamps

qnas.question: I noticed that when I add an object which is not defined by the schema, then Weaviate auto generates a class in the schema. Is it possible to configure Weaviate to be more strict and return a validation error?
alternativeQuestions: Can I stop Weaviate from creating a class for an object that isn't yet defined?
qnas.answer:
You can disable autoschema entirely by setting the environment variable AUTOSCHEMA_ENABLED: 'false'

Also see https://www.semi.technology/developers/weaviate/current/data-schema/schema-configuration.html#auto-schema

qnas.question: How to search for answers contained by data / objects?
alternativeQuestions: How can I extract answers from data / objects?
qnas.answer:
Please see

  • https://www.semi.technology/developers/weaviate/current/modules/qna-transformers.html

Or try the following query:

                                          {
  Get {
    Qna(ask: {question:"How to find an answer to a question",certainty: 0.5}, limit: 10) {
      question
      answer
      _additional{
        certainty
        id
      }
    }
  }

qnas.question: How are references deleted?
alternativeQuestions: How is deleting of references done?
qnas.answer: References aren’t cleaned up automatically at the moment. However, references which cannot be resolved at runtime are simply ignored.

qnas.question: What is Weaviate?
alternativeQuestions: Can you introduce me to Weaviate?
qnas.answer:
Weaviate is a vector search engine and vector database. Weaviate uses machine learning to vectorize and store data, and to find answers to natural language queries. With Weaviate you can also bring your custom ML models to production scale. 

Get more information here !

qnas.question: Why do I receive the error "unmarshal response body: invalid character" when importing data?
alternativeQuestions: "unmarshal response body: invalid character" is the error I get when importing data, what's happening?
qnas.answer: Most likely your string is not JSON.

qnas.question: How to import data / objects?
alternativeQuestions: How is importing of data or objects done?
qnas.answer:
Please see

  • https://www.semi.technology/developers/weaviate/current/tutorials/how-to-import-data.html

Or try the following example:

curl -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d '{ "class":"Qna", "id":"f044b45c-d7c3-44bf-9a1f-4fb424ff6b07", "properties":{ "question":"How to import data / objects?", "answer":"Please see https://www.semi.technology/developers/weaviate/current/tutorials/how-to-import-data.html" } }' http://localhost:8080/v1/objects

qnas.question: Are both semantic search & QA tasks always combined or is it possible to uniquely use semantic search?
alternativeQuestions: Can I use semantic search without QA tasks?
qnas.answer:
You can use semantic search in isolation. See nearText if you are running with a  text2vec  module or  nearVector  and  nearObject  which always work - even if you don't use any modules. 

Qna, however, depends on performing a semantic search first, so that one cannot be used in isolation. The idea is that the semantic search will find the right snippet, the qna module will extract the answer from that snippet.

(To learn more  about modules, see this section ).

qnas.question: Where can I download the news-publication data?
alternativeQuestions: Can you please link me the news-publication data so I can download it?
qnas.answer: Please see https://github.com/semi-technologies/DEMO-NewsPublications/

qnas.question: How can I run the latest master branch with docker-compose?
alternativeQuestions: When using docker-compose, how can I run the latest master branch?
qnas.answer:
You can run Weaviate with `docker-compose`, you can build your own container off the [`master`](https://github.com/semi-technologies/weaviate) branch. Note that this is not an officially released Weaviate version, so this might contain bugs.

```sh
git clone https://github.com/semi-technologies/weaviate.git
cd weaviate
docker build ++target weaviate -t name-of-your-weaviate-image .
```

Then, make a `docker-compose.yml` file with this new image. For example:

```yml
version: '3.4'
services:
  weaviate:
    image: name-of-your-weaviate-image
    ports:
      - 8080:8080
    environment:
      CONTEXTIONARY_URL: contextionary:9999
      QUERY_DEFAULTS_LIMIT: 25
      AUTHENTICATION_ANONYMOUS_ACCESS_ENABLED: 'true'
      PERSISTENCE_DATA_PATH: './data'
      ENABLE_MODULES: 'text2vec-contextionary'
      DEFAULT_VECTORIZER_MODULE: 'text2vec-contextionary'
      AUTOSCHEMA_ENABLED: 'false'
  contextionary:
    environment:
      OCCURRENCE_WEIGHT_LINEAR_FACTOR: 0.75
      EXTENSIONS_STORAGE_MODE: weaviate
      EXTENSIONS_STORAGE_ORIGIN: http://weaviate:8080
      NEIGHBOR_OCCURRENCE_IGNORE_PERCENTILE: 5
      ENABLE_COMPOUND_SPLITTING: 'false'
    image: semitechnologies/contextionary:en0.16.0-v1.0.2
```

After the build is complete, you can run this Weaviate build with docker-compose: `docker-compose up`.

qnas.question: What happens when the weaviate docker container restarts? Is my data in the weaviate database lost?
alternativeQuestions: What is happening on a Weaviate docker container restart? Where is my database?
qnas.answer:
There are three levels:
1. You have no volume configured (the default in our `docker-compose` files), if the container restarts (e.g. due to a crash, or because of `docker stop/start`) your data is kept
2. You have no volume configured (the default in our `docker-compose` files), if the container is removed (e.g. from `docker-compose down` or `docker rm`) your data is gone
3. If a volume is configured, your data is persisted regardless of what happens to the container. They can be completely removed or replaced, next time they start up with a volume, all your data will be there

qnas.question: Is there support to multiple versions of the query/document embedding models to co-exist at a given time? (helps with live experiments of new model versions)
alternativeQuestions: Can multiple versions of document embedding models exist at the same time to help with experiments?
qnas.answer: You can create multiple classes in the Weaviate schema, where one class will act like a namespace in Kubernetes or an index in Elasticsearch. So the spaces will be completely independent, this allows space 1 to use completely different embeddings from space 2. The configured vectorizer is always scoped only to a single class. You can also use Weaviate's Cross-Reference features to make a graph-like connection between an object of Class 1 to the corresponding object of Class 2 to make it easy to see the equivalent in the other space.

qnas.question: If I run a cluster (multiple instances) of Weaviate, do all the instances have to share a filesystem(PERSISTENCE_DATA_PATH)?
alternativeQuestions: When running a Weaviate cluster, do they all have to share a filesystem PERSISTENCE_DATA_PATH?
qnas.answer:
Horizontal Scalability is currently under development with an ETA for end of Q3 in 2021. Once it’s in it will not share filesystems, but each node will be truly independent with their own filesystem. The partitioning and replication strategies are modelled after Cassandra and Elasticsearch (Cassandra with regards to the virtual nodes in a ring, ES with regards to shards, because we need explicit shards for searching, whereas cassandra would only support direct access by (primary and partitioning) key. Until then Weaviate is currently confined to a single node. If you were to try to run two processes trying to access the same classes, I think it would fail, as each process would try to obtain a lock on the same files.

We have recently implemented a LSM tree based approached to storage in Weaviate v1.5: Object and Index storage is no longer done using a B+Tree approach (bolb/bbolt), but uses a custom LSM tree approach. This speeds up imports by over 100% depending on the use case.

qnas.question: What is the different between `text` and `string` and `valueText` and `valueString`?
alternativeQuestions: Is there a difference between 'text' and 'string'? and 'valueText' and 'valueString?
qnas.answer: In general `value<Text|String>` should always match the data type in your schema. `text` is tokenized into basically just letters and numbers, whereas `string` is not tokenized. So if you want to have exact matches like email addresses use `string` and `valueString` because `text`/`valueText` would also match e.g. `jane doe` for `jane@doe.com`.

qnas.question: Should I use references in my schema?
alternativeQuestions: Should references be used in the schema?
qnas.answer:
In short: for convenience you can add relations to your data schema, because you need less code and queries to get data. But resolving references in queries takes some of the performance.

1. If your ultimate goal is performance, references probably don’t add any value, as resolving them adds a cost.
2. If your goal is represent complex relationships between your data items, they can help a lot. You can resolve references in a single query, so if you have classes with multiple links, it could definitely be helpful to resolve some of those connections in a single query. On the other hand, if you have a single (bi-directional) reference in your data, you could also just denormalize the links (e.g. with an ID field) and resolve them during search.

qnas.question: With relation to "filtered vector search”: Since this is a two-phase pipeline, how big can that list of IDs get? Do you know how that size might affect query performance?
alternativeQuestions: In a two-phase pipeline how many IDs can there be for filtered vector search? how is performance affected when querying?
qnas.answer:
Essentially the list ids uses the internal doc id which is a `uint64` or 8 bytes per ID. The list can grow as long as you have memory available. So for example with 2GB of free memory, it could hold 250M ids, with 20GB it could hold 2.5B ids, etc.

Performance wise there are two things to consider:
1. Building the lookup list
2. Filtering the results when vector searching

Building the list is a typical inverted index look up, so depending on the operator this is just a single read on == (or a set of range reads, e.g. for >7, we'd read the value rows from 7 to infinity). This process is pretty efficient, similar to how the same thing would happen in a traditional search engine, such as elasticsearch

Performing the filtering during the vector search depends on whether the filter is very restrictive or very loose. In the case you mentioned where a lot of IDs are included, it will be very efficient. Because the equivalent of an unfiltered search would be the one where your ID list contains all possible IDs. So the HNSW index would behave normally. There is however, a small penalty whenever a list is present: We need to check if the current ID is contained an the allow-list. This is essentially a hashmap lookup, so it should be O(1) per object. Nevertheless, there is a slight performance penalty.

Now the other extreme, a very restrictive list, i.e few IDs on the list, actually takes considerably more time. Because the HNSW index will find neighboring IDs, but since they're not contained, they cannot be added as result candidates, meaning that all we can do with them is evaluating their connections, but not the points themselves. In the extreme case of a list that is very, very restrictive, say just 10 objects out of 1B in the worst case the search would become exhaustive if you the filtered ids are very far from the query. In this extreme case, it would actually be much more efficient to just skip the index and do a brute-force indexless vector search on the 10 ids. So, there is a cut-off when a brute-force search becomes more efficient than a heavily-restricted vector search with HNSW. We do not yet have any optimization to discovery such a cut-off point and skip the index, but this should be fairly simple to implement if this ever becomes an actual problem.

qnas.question: What would you say is more important for query speed in Weaviate: More CPU power, or more RAM?
alternativeQuestions: For query speed, what is more important, CPU power or RAM?
qnas.answer:
More concretely: If you had to pick between a machine that has 16 GB of RAM and 2 CPUs, or a machine that has 8 GB of RAM and 4 CPUs, which would you pick?

This is a very difficult to answer 100% correctly, because there are several factors in play:
* **The vector search itself**. This part is CPU-bound, however only with regards to throughput: A single search is single-threaded. Multiple parallel searches can use multiple threads. So if you measure the time of a single request (otherwise idle), it will be the same whether the machine has 1 core or 100. However, if your QPS approach the throughput of a CPU, you'll see massive benefits by adding more Cores
* **The retrieval of the objects**. Once the vector search part is done, we are essentially left with a list of n IDs which need to be resolved to actual objects. This is IO-bound in general. However, all disk files are memory-mapped. So generally, more mem will allow you to hold more of the disk state in memory. In real life however, it's not that simple. Searches are rarely evenly distributed. So let's pretend that 90% of searches will return just 10% of objects (because these are more popular search results). Then if those 10% of the disk objects are already cached in mem, there's no benefit in adding more memory.

Taking the above in mind: we can carefully say: If throughput is the problem, increase CPU, if response time is the problem increase mem. However, note that the latter only adds value if there are more things that can be cached. If you have enough mem to cache your entire disk state (or at least the parts that are relevant for most queries), additional memory won't add any additional benefit.
If we are talking about imports on the other hand, they are almost always CPU-bound because of the cost of creating the HNSW index. So, if you can resize between import and query, my recommendation would be roughly prefer CPUs while importing and then gradually replace CPU with memory at query time - until you see no more benefits. (This assumes that there is a separation between importing and querying which might not always be the case in real life).

qnas.question: Does Weaviate require NFS volumes on Kubernetes?
alternativeQuestions: When running Weaviate on Kubernetes, do I need to use NFS volumes?
qnas.answer: By default, no NFS volumes are active. In a production setting, we recommend turning etcd disaster recovery on which requires an NFS volume. However, [the helm docs](../getting-started/installation.html) contain instructions on how to deploy an nfs-provisioner. For more details, see also this [stack overflow answer](https://stackoverflow.com/a/60505796/5322199).

qnas.question: Can I request a feature in Weaviate?
alternativeQuestions: Is there a feature request form for Weaviate?
qnas.answer: Sure (also, feel free to [issue a pull request](https://github.com/semi-technologies/weaviate/pulls) 😉) you can [add those requests here](https://github.com/semi-technologies/weaviate/issues). The only thing you need is a Github account, and while you're there, make sure to give us a star 😇.

qnas.question: Do I need to know about Docker (Compose) to use Weaviate?
alternativeQuestions: Is knowledge about Docker compose necessary to use Weaviate?
qnas.answer: Weaviate uses Docker images as a means to distribute releases and uses Docker Compose to tie a module-rich runtime together. If you are new to those technologies, we recommend reading the [Docker Introduction for Weaviate Users](https://medium.com/semi-technologies/what-weaviate-users-should-know-about-docker-containers-1601c6afa079).

qnas.question: Data import takes long / is slow (slower than before v1.0.0), what is causing this and what can I do?
alternativeQuestions: Did something in v1.0.0 cause a slowing down of data import or what could be the cause of this?
qnas.answer: The first supported vector index type HNSW is super fast at query time, but slower on vectorization. This means that adding and updating data objects costs relatively more time. When there are other vector index types available, you van try another vector index type.

qnas.question: What is the difference between Weaviate and for example Elasticsearch?
alternativeQuestions: Is there a difference between Elasticsearch and Weaviate?
qnas.answer: Other database systems like Elasticsearch rely on inverted indices, which makes search super fast. Weaviate also uses inverted indices to store data and values. But additionally, Weaviate is also a vector-native search database, which means that data is stored as vectors, which enables semantic search. This combination of data storage is unique, and enables fast, filtered and semantic search from end-to-end.

qnas.question: How do you deal with words that have multiple meanings?
alternativeQuestions: What can be done about words with multiple meanings?
qnas.answer: How can Weaviate interpret that you mean a company, as in business, and not as the division of the army? We do this based on the structure of the schema and the data you add. A schema in Weaviate might contain a company class with the property name and the value Apple. This simple representation (company, name, apple) is already enough to gravitate the vector position of the data object towards businesses or the iPhone. You can read [here](../) how we do this, or you can ask a specific question on [Stackoverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/tags/weaviate/) and tag it with Weaviate.

qnas.question: How can you index data near-realtime without losing semantic meaning?
alternativeQuestions: Is there a way to index data almost in realtime without losing semantic meaning?
qnas.answer: Every data object [gets its vector representation](../) based on its semantic meaning. In a nutshell, we calculate the vector position of the data object based on the words and concepts used in the data object. The existing model in the contextionary gives already enough context. If you want to get in the nitty-gritty, you can [browse the code here](https://github.com/semi-technologies/contextionary/tree/master/server), but you can also ask a [specific question on Stackoverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/tags/weaviate/) and tag it with Weaviate.

qnas.question: How to deal with custom terminology?
alternativeQuestions: How should custom terminology be handled?
qnas.answer: Sometimes, users work with custom terminology, which often comes in the form of abbreviations or jargon. We are currently working on an additional API endpoint, which allows you to add custom synonyms. You can find the state of the implementation [here](https://github.com/semi-technologies/weaviate/issues/946). You can also signup for our [newsletter](http://weaviate-newsletter.semi.technology/) to receive an update when it is ready.

qnas.question: Can I use Weaviate to create a traditional knowledge graph.
alternativeQuestions: I would like to create a regular knowledge graph, can this be done with Weaviate?
qnas.answer: Yes, you can! Weaviate support ontology, RDF-like definitions in its schema, and it runs out of the box. It is scalable, and the GraphQL API will allow you to query through your knowledge graph easily. But now you are here. We like to suggest you really try its semantic features. After all, you are creating a _knowledge_ graph 😉.

qnas.question: What is the difference between a Weaviate data schema, ontologies and taxonomies?
alternativeQuestions: Can you explain to me the differences between data schema, ontologies and toxonomies in Weaviate?
qnas.answer: Read about how taxonomies, ontologies and schemas are related to Weaviate in [this blog post](https://medium.com/semi-technologies/taxonomies-ontologies-and-schemas-how-do-they-relate-to-weaviate-9f76739fc695).

qnas.question: Why does Weaviate have a schema and not an ontology?
alternativeQuestions: What is the reason for Weaviate to have schemas but not ontologies?
qnas.answer: We use a schema because it focusses on the representation of your data (in our case in the GraphQL API) but you can use a Weaviate schema to express an ontology. One of Weaviate's core features is that it semantically interprets your schema (and with that your ontology) so that you can search for concepts rather than formally defined entities.

qnas.question: Can I train my own text2vec-contextionary vectorizer module?
alternativeQuestions: I would like to train my custom text2vec-contextionary vectorizer model, is that possible?
qnas.answer: Not yet (but soon), you can currently use the [available contextionaries](../getting-started/installation.html) in a variety of languages and use the transfer learning feature to add custom concepts if needed. Sign up to our [newsletter](http://weaviate-newsletter.semi.technology/) or [Slack channel]({{ site.slack_signup_url }}) to keep updated about the release of custom contextionary training

qnas.question: What is Weaviate's consistency model in a distributed setup?
alternativeQuestions: Using a distributed setup, what consistency model is Weaviate using?
qnas.answer:
Weaviate is generally modeled to prefer Availability over Consistency (AP over CP). It is designed to deliver low search latencies under high throughput in situations where availability is more business-critical than consistency. If strict serializability is required on your data, we generally recommend storing your data in a different primary data store, use Weaviate as an auxiliary data store, and set up replication between the two. If you do not need serializability and eventual consistency is enough for your use case, Weaviate can be used as a primary datastore.

Weaviate has no notion of transactions, operations always affect exactly a single key, therefore Serializability is not applicable. In a distributed setup (under development) Weaviate's consistency model is eventual consistency. When a cluster is healthy, all changes are replicated to all affected nodes by the time the write is acknowledged by the user. Objects will immediately be present in search results on all nodes after the import request completes. If a search query occurs concurrently with an import operation nodes may not be in sync yet. This means some nodes might already include the newly added or updated objects, while others don't yet. In a healthy cluster, all nodes will have converged by the time the import request has been completed successfully. If a node is temporarily unavailable and rejoins a cluster it may temporarily be out of sync. It will then sync the missed changes from other replica nodes and eventually serve the same data again.

qnas.question: Is it possible to apply re-ranking after semantic search and what algorithm is used for re-ranking?
alternativeQuestions: Can I re-rank results after semantic search? what would the re-ranking algorithm be?
qnas.answer: There is no re-ranking out-of-the-box yet, however, you can create a custom module  which could run arbitrary code to influence the results in anyway possible. Out-of-the-box reranking mechanism will probably also be offered at some point in the future.

qnas.question: Would it be possible to have audio/video datasets as inputs?
alternativeQuestions: Can I use audio or video data as inputs?
qnas.answer: It is possible too have other sorts of datasets as inputs. If there are no out-of-the-box modules,  they could easily be created. Generally anything that can be vectorized can be used with Weaviate. You can also vectorize anything outside of Weaviate using any model and import the vectors (instead of letting Weaviate determine them.

qnas.question: Would it be possible to use a custom dataset?
alternativeQuestions: Can I use my own dataset?
qnas.answer: Weaviate was built around the idea that you own your data (hence the ability to self-host) and you can get more insights into your data.

qnas.question: What is the recommended way to back up my Weaviate database?
alternativeQuestions: Is there a guide for backing up a Weaviate database?
qnas.answer:
The Weaviate data is located by default inside your Docker container at /var/lib/weaviate . Make sure to mount this directory (for example use volumes inside docker-compose) and then do a backup of the mounted directory/volume.

For further details please see https://www.semi.technology/developers/weaviate/current/configuration/backups-and-persistence.html

Also see https://app.katie.qa/#/read-answer?domain-id=ceb2d2f2-2c1d-49be-a751-eed4be19e021&uuid=8258b26c-887e-4d5f-824d-fbcdb806a9e9

qnas.question: Are all ANN algorithms potential candidates to become an indexation plugin in Weaviate?
alternativeQuestions: Can I use all ANN algorithms as an indexation plugin in Weaviate?
qnas.answer:
No

Some algorithms (e.g., Annoy or ScaNN) are entirely immutable once built, they can neither be changed nor built up incrementally. Instead, they require you to have all of your vectors present, then you build the algorithm once. After a build, you can only query them, but cannot add more elements or change existing elements. Thus, they aren’t capable of the CRUD operations we want to support in Weaviate.

qnas.question: When I combine ask and where in a query, does the order matter?
alternativeQuestions: How does the order affect the result when querying ask and where?
qnas.answer: The order in the query has no meaning, a filter like for example "where" is always applied first and a vector search like for example "ask" (which is what qna is under the hood) is applied on the reduced dataset

qnas.question: Why do I receive the error "is not a valid class name" when uploading a schema with multiple classes using curl?
alternativeQuestions: "is not a valid class name" this is the error I get when uploading a schema with more than one class using curl, why?
qnas.answer:
Assuming you were sending a POST to /v1/schema . In this case you need to upload one class at a time, i.e. instead of sending the whole schema with two classes, you need to send each class separately.

See also this example (switch to the curl tab): https://www.semi.technology/developers/weaviate/current/restful-api-references/schema.html#example-request-for-creating-a-class

qnas.question: Why are my schema and data lost when I restart Weaviate Docker?
alternativeQuestions: I lost all my data and the schema when restarting Weaviate, what is happening?
qnas.answer: The Weaviate schema and data is located by default inside your Docker container. Make sure to mount the Weaviate volume, whereas see for example https://stackoverflow.com/a/70215384/12727278

qnas.question: Does Weaviate support multi-tenancy?
alternativeQuestions: Can I use more than one tenant in Weaviate?
qnas.answer:
You can separate data by creating separate classes (i.e. each class is its own folder on disk), but we don't currently have authorization rules to make sure individual user can only access individual classes. This is something you'd have to do at an application level. Similarly each class name would have to be unique (e.g. by using a tenant-specific prefix)

If each tenant is large enough it might also make sense to deploy one instance/cluster per tenant. This way you'd isolate failure domains (i.e if one tenant manages to somehow crash the setup, it wouldn't cascade to others)

qnas.question: Do you offer Weaviate as a managed service?
alternativeQuestions: Can I pay you for hosting Weaviate as a managed service?
qnas.answer: Yes, it is called the Weaviate Console .

qnas.question: Why would I use Weaviate as my vector search engine?
alternativeQuestions: Why should I use Weaviate as my DB?
qnas.answer: Our goal is three-folded. Firstly, we want to make it as easy as possible for others to create their own semantic systems or vector search engines (hence, we are API based). Secondly, we have a strong focus on the semantic element (the “knowledge” in “vector search engine,” if you will). Our ultimate goal is to have Weaviate help you manage, index, and “understand” your data so that you can build newer, better, and faster applications. And thirdly, we want you to be able to run it everywhere. This is the reason why Weaviate comes containerized.
